bibl.title: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Frederick F. Russell, November 24, 1929

div1.p: Carter explains the supplementary work she is doing on the manuscript of the History of Yellow Fever as she waits to hear from Frost about when he can resume work.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Frederick F. Russell, November 24, 1929
div1.opener:
Book. Misel. Russell,
Report
The Westmoreland,
2122 California St., N. W.
Washington, D. C.
November 24, 1929.
Dear Doctor Russell:
div1.p:
Since I had the very real pleasure of seeing you last
Octovber, at the dedication of the William Welch Library. I have been,
while awaiting Dr. Frost's return to Baltimore and the final editing,
putting in considerable supplementary work on Father's book. Certainly,
as Frost says: “there is no end to what one can do” on a book! About
every other day I go to my desk at the Library of Congress and always
find something worth the doing there in the way of additional checking,
simplification or elaboration of references etc. etc.

I have gotten our two maps from Mr. Weckerly, Chief Illustra-
tor of the Geological Survey. These (tentatively filled in in pencil)
Miss Brown and I have most carefully checked from our alphabetic
cards of places mentioned in Father's MS. We have noted such corrections
and additions as seemed advisable. I shall not, of course, have
them inked in until Dr. Frost has seen them.

I have also been going over a lot of biographic material about
Father, in order to have it ready for Dr. Frost when, the final editing
completed, he starts the biographic sketch, which you so fortunately
asked him to write for the book. This, because when Frost does be-
gin to send us the final bibliographic cards to be cleared up, there
will, of course, be a time of stress and “night shifts” and I there-
forewant to everything done that I possibly can before this time.

I understand that Dr. Frost is at last back in Baltimore. I
have not heard from him directly, but am hoping that his other duties
will now allow him to resume the final editing. Mrs. Frost has asked
asked
-2-
me over for the latter part of this week, when I hope to take up
the matter of the maps with him and anything else that he may suggest
or have ready for me to do.
div1.closer:
With best wishes, I remain
Very truly yours, Laura A. Carter Dr. F. F. Russell, Director,
International Health Division
The Rockefeller Foundation,
61 Broadway, New York, N. Y.
